page.title: 13BISHOP OF CARLISLE: CAREER
page.content: Henry David Halsey was made Bishop of Carlisle in 1972. He is the 64th Bishop of Carlisle and this is his last year of office. He is tall and of a slender build with grey hair. When he first started in the Church he was an assistant vicar for four to five years. After a lot of hard work he became a vicar. He was soon invited to become Rural Dean and then became Archdeacon. He proved to be a good Archdeacon and was asked to be Assistant to the Bishop. In 1972 he eventually became the Bishop of Carlisle and entered the House of Lords. The Bishop attended the ten yearly Lambeth Conference in 1978, and has attended conferences in Zululand and Matabeleland.
